support_summary: CASP7 (Caspase-7) physically binds and cleaves specific isoforms of ATXN3 (Co-IP evidence)

functions.effect_description: Caspase-7 cleaves ATXN3 to generate truncated, highly toxic, and aggregation-prone C-terminal fragments.
biological_consequence: Apoptotic stimulus → Activation of Caspase-7 → Recognition of DXXD motifs (D241/D244/D248) in ATXN3 → Proteolytic cleavage → Release of ~28-37 kDa C-terminal polyQ fragments → Enhanced nucleation and aggregate formation → Increased neurotoxicity.
specific_effects: Generation of ~28 kDa and ~37 kDa ATXN3 fragments
Increased rate of SDS-insoluble aggregate formation
Enhanced nuclear accumulation of polyQ-containing fragments

evidence.paper_title: Caspase-mediated proteolysis of the polyglutamine disease protein ataxin-3
evidence.relevant_quote: Caspase-mediated cleavage of expanded ataxin-3 resulted in increased ataxin-3 aggregation, suggesting a potential role for caspase-mediated proteolysis in spinocerebellar ataxia type-3 pathogenesis.

mechanism_correction: Confirmed: Caspase-7 (along with Caspase-1 and Caspase-3) cleaves ATXN3 at specific aspartate residues (D241, D244, and D248) located near the polyglutamine tract. This cleavage releases C-terminal fragments containing the expanded polyQ repeat, which are significantly more prone to aggregation and nuclear translocation than the full-length protein, thereby driving pathogenesis.
effect: Caspase-7 cleaves ATXN3 to generate truncated, highly toxic, and aggregation-prone C-terminal fragments.
summary: ATXN3 activates CASP7 to modulate atxn3 proteolysis, ultimately affecting increased neurotoxicity.
